{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":6815,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_level":"Moderate","common_name":"shrub rose","description":"The Shrub Rose (Rosa 'Chewground' OSO EASY FRAGRANT SPREADER) is an easy-to-grow plant that is perfect for any garden landscape. This rose produces abundant, fragrant blooms with shades ranging from apricots to dark purples and reds. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":6851,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"hybrid tea rose","description":"The Hybrid Tea Rose 'Korbilant' PAROLE is an exquisite plant that combine classic beauty with modern charm. It is known to offer up showy, double petals splashed in shades of salmon pink, orange and raspberry. At the center a small yellow eye is surrounded by a gold-yellow halo. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":6885,"attracts":["Birds"," Butterflies"],"care_level":"High","common_name":"swamp rose","description":"The swamp rose, or Rosa palustris, is a deciduous shrub native to swamps, marshes, and wetlands. It has arching branches and can grow up to 5 feet tall. The foliage is a deep green color and has a jagged leaf edge. Rugosa roses have thick, shiny, dark green leaves and purplish-red stems that are arching and bristly. The bright red fruits are persistent through winter and attract many birds. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":6925,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"hybrid tea rose","description":"Hybrid Tea Rose (Rosa 'Tanellis' FRAGRANT CLOUD) is a popular choice for your garden due to its beauty and fragrance. Its jagged leaves make it an excellent natural barrier to unwanted visitors and it is often used for erosion control and in landscaping. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":6883,"attracts":["Birds"," Butterflies"],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"damask rose","description":"The Damask Rose (Rosa 'Omar Khayyam') is a versatile rose bush that provides an abundance of beauty with its single, semi-double and fully double blossoms. A very versatile plant, it can be grown as a shrub or bush, and even as a climbing plant. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":6922,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"prairie rose","description":"Prairie rose (Rosa setigera), a deciduous shrub native to the United States, is a favored garden and landscaping plant. Standing at two to four feet in height, the prairie rose produces delicate and fragrant, pink to white flowers during early summer. It is relatively pest and disease-free, making it a perfect choice for low-maintenance gardens. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":6933,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"floribunda rose","description":"Floribunda rose (Rosa 'Wekplapep' SCENTIMENTAL) is a highly fragrant and attractive plant species. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":6944,"attracts":[],"care_level":"Moderate","common_name":"roscoea","description":"Roscoea auriculata 'Beesiana' is an enchanting garden variety with long-spurted blooms that nearly reach the ground. This species of Indian ginger adds an interesting vertical element to garden beds. It's spires of nodding purple-mauve flowers bloom in summer above lush, green foliage that often turns a vivid yellow in autumn. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":6994,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"cutleaf coneflower","description":"The cutleaf coneflower is a native plant of the United States. It is an easy-to-grow perennial with beautiful yellow blooms resembling stars. Its particularly attractive feature is its deeply-divided foliage that gives the plant a lacy appearance. The flowers have yellow-orange petals that form a central cone, with the petals produced in threes. The blooms appear in midsummer and continue through fall. Cutleaf coneflower can grow up to 8 feet tall and is a great addition to any garden or meadow. Its bright and cheerful flowers provide a lovely backdrop in any garden setting.","family":"Asteraceae","flower_color":"Yellow rays and green center disks","flowering_season":null,"fruit_color":["brown"],"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":[],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division","Root Cutting","Layering Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March","April","March","April","June","July","August","June","July","August"],"scientific_name":["Rudbeckia laciniata"],"soil":["Loamy Clay Humus"],"watering_period":null}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":6995,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"cutleaf coneflower","description":"The Cutleaf Coneflower, or Rudbeckia laciniata 'Hortensia', is a hardy perennial with eye-catching, divided green leaves. Bright yellow daisy-like flowers with lacy petals and dark brown centers bloom from mid-summer to late fall. Growing up to 8 ft. tall and wide, this plant should be planted in an area with plenty of room to spread. Thriving in full to partial sun and average soil, it produces more flowers when exposed to higher levels of sunlight. Cutleaf Coneflower attracts bees, butterflies, and other beneficial pollinators and provides stunning and unique late summer and fall color to the garden.","family":"Asteraceae","flower_color":"Yellow rays and green center disks","flowering_season":null,"fruit_color":["brown"],"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Fall","leaf_color":["green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":[],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division","Root Cutting","Stem Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February","March","April","June","July","August"],"scientific_name":["Rudbeckia laciniata 'Hortensia'"],"soil":["Loamy Clay Humus"],"watering_period":null}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":6996,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"large coneflower","description":"Large coneflower (Rudbeckia maxima) is a tall, bright, and majestic wildflower native to prairies and savannas of the United States. It grows up to 8 feet tall and has bright yellow rays with long, dark, spiny bracts that surround the dark central cone. These blooms attract many beneficial pollinators including butterflies and bees. Its deeply lobed leaves are dark green and grow in an alternate pattern. Large coneflower is perfect for large flower beds and dramatic border plantings and creates a showy habitat for wildlife.","family":"Asteraceae","flower_color":"Yellow rays surround dark brown center cone","flowering_season":null,"fruit_color":[],"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Central and southern United States"],"other_name":[],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division","Root Cutting","Stem Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March","April"],"scientific_name":["Rudbeckia maxima"],"soil":[],"watering_period":null}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":6997,"attracts":["Birds"," Butterflies"],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"large coneflower","description":"The Large Coneflower (Rudbeckia maxima 'Golda Emanis') is an impressive flowering perennial which produces bold yellow blossoms with deep bronze-orange centers. It's an elegant flower which grows to between 45-90 cm and blooms from mid-summer to early autumn. The Large Coneflower is deer and rabbit resistant and very easy to maintain. It's suited to both garden and wildflower meadows and when cultivated in the proper conditions, it will keep coming back year after year. Its upright stems and low profile help it to mix well with many other species of plants and make it an excellent choice for small city gardens.","family":"Asteraceae","flower_color":"Golden yellow with a dark brown central cone","flowering_season":null,"fruit_color":[],"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["gold","green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":[],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division","Root Cutting","Stem Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Rudbeckia maxima 'Golda Emanis'"],"soil":[],"watering_period":null}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":6998,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Missouri coneflower","description":"The Missouri coneflower is a beautiful tall wildflower native to the midwestern United States. It is a member of the daisy family and its cheery orange-yellow flowers blossom in the summertime. It grows in moist prairies and limestone out-croppings and its white-fuzzy leaves usually reach up to three feet high. The Missouri coneflower has a prominent central disc, surrounded by slightly drooping bright yellow petals, and sits at the tops of dark green, hairy stems. These unique flowers attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies and can be found decorating the prairies of the Midwest.","family":"Asteraceae","flower_color":"Orange, yellow","flowering_season":null,"fruit_color":[],"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southern and central United States"],"other_name":[],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division","Root Cutting","Layering Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February","March","April"],"scientific_name":["Rudbeckia missouriensis"],"soil":[],"watering_period":"night"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":7000,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"coneflower","description":"Coneflower (Rudbeckia occidentalis 'Green Wizard') is a daisy-like perennial plant with bright green foliage and large yellow-brown flowers blooming from late summer into autumn. The flowers have an interesting conical look hence the common name. It is perfect for growing in borders and naturalizing in meadows as it will self-seed. It is a herbaceous perennial species, preferring full sun and well-drained soil. It has a vigorous habit and grows rapidly making it a great choice for filling up larger empty spaces. Coneflower is simple to maintain and it is said to attract bees and other pollinators.","family":"Asteraceae","flower_color":"Purple to black disk atop green bracts","flowering_season":null,"fruit_color":["green","brown"],"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Fall","leaf_color":["green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Garden origin"],"other_name":["western coneflower"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February","March","April"],"scientific_name":["Rudbeckia occidentalis 'Green Wizard'"],"soil":[],"watering_period":null}}

Coneflowers grow to the height of 3-4 feet tall and about 1-2 feet wide, blooming from late summer into fall.
